title: What is a process and process table?
subject: OS
answer: A process is a program in execution. The OS tracks processes in a process table, which stores state, registers, memory info, open files and scheduling details.

title: What are the different states of a process?
subject: OS
answer: A process may be in states: New, Ready, Running, Waiting/Blocked and Terminated. Real systems maintain ready and waiting queues.

title: What is a thread?
subject: OS
answer: A thread is the smallest execution unit inside a process. Threads share code, data and heap but have their own stack and registers. They enable parallelism.

title: Difference between process and thread
subject: OS
answer: Processes have separate memory and require IPC. Threads share memory in the same process and communicate faster. Process switching is heavier than thread switching.

title: Benefits of multithreaded programming
subject: OS
answer: Improves responsiveness, resource sharing, throughput, economy, scalability and better CPU utilization.

title: What is thrashing?
subject: OS
answer: Thrashing occurs when the system spends more time handling page faults than executing processes due to insufficient memory.

title: What is a buffer?
subject: OS
answer: A buffer is a temporary memory area used to store data during transfer between devices or applications.

title: What is virtual memory?
subject: OS
answer: Virtual memory allows a program to use more logical memory than physically available by storing inactive pages on disk and loading them when needed.

title: Main purpose of an Operating System
subject: OS
answer: Acts as an interface between users and hardware, manages resources, ensures safe execution, and improves convenience and efficiency.

title: What is demand paging?
subject: OS
answer: Only the required pages of a process are loaded into RAM when they are accessed. Missing pages cause a page fault and are loaded from disk.

title: What is a kernel?
subject: OS
answer: The kernel is the core of the OS. It manages CPU, memory, devices, processes and system calls, acting as bridge between apps and hardware.

title: Different scheduling algorithms
subject: OS
answer: FCFS, SJF, Priority Scheduling, Shortest Remaining Time, Round Robin, Multilevel Queue, Multilevel Feedback Queue.

title: Objective of multiprogramming
subject: OS
answer: Increase CPU utilization by keeping multiple jobs in memory so CPU always has something to execute.

title: What is time-sharing?
subject: OS
answer: Logical extension of multiprogramming where CPU switches frequently, giving each user interactive access.

title: Problems without an OS
subject: OS
answer: No resource management, no UI, no filesystem, no multitasking, poor security, no networking, unreliable execution.

title: Explain FCFS scheduling
subject: OS
answer: Jobs are executed in order of arrival. Non-preemptive. Long jobs cause long waiting time (convoy effect).

title: What is Round Robin scheduling?
subject: OS
answer: Each process gets a fixed time slice. After quantum expires, process is preempted. Prevents starvation and is fair.

title: Different RAID levels
subject: OS
answer: RAID 0,1,2,3,4,5,6. Provide redundancy, reliability and performance improvements.

title: What is Banker’s algorithm?
subject: OS
answer: Deadlock avoidance algorithm that checks whether granting a request keeps the system in a safe state.

title: Logical vs Physical address
subject: OS
answer: Logical address is generated by CPU. Physical address is actual RAM location computed by MMU. Users see only logical addresses.

title: How does dynamic loading help?
subject: OS
answer: Routines are loaded only when needed, saving memory and improving space utilization.

title: What are overlays?
subject: OS
answer: Technique where only required parts of program are loaded, replacing others to save memory.

title: What is fragmentation?
subject: OS
answer: Small unusable memory gaps are formed when processes are allocated and removed from memory.

title: What is paging?
subject: OS
answer: Memory is divided into fixed-size pages and frames. Pages of a process are loaded into any free frame, allowing non-contiguous allocation.

title: What is swapping?
subject: OS
answer: Temporarily moving processes to disk and back to memory to increase degree of multiprogramming.

title: Classic synchronization problems
subject: OS
answer: Bounded Buffer, Readers-Writers, Dining Philosophers, Sleeping Barber.

title: What is Direct Access Method?
subject: OS
answer: Allows arbitrary blocks to be read or written like an array of records. Often associated with disk addressing.

title: When does thrashing occur?
subject: OS
answer: When processes frequently access pages not in memory causing excessive paging.

title: What is multitasking?
subject: OS
answer: Multiple processes execute concurrently sharing CPU and other system resources.

title: What is caching?
subject: OS
answer: Using a small fast memory to store frequently accessed data to reduce average access time.

title: What is spooling?
subject: OS
answer: Data is queued in buffer and sent to slower devices asynchronously, allowing CPU to continue work.

title: Function of assembler
subject: OS
answer: Converts assembly language into machine code.

title: What are interrupts?
subject: OS
answer: Signals from hardware or software requiring CPU to stop current execution and handle event.

title: What is GUI?
subject: OS
answer: Graphical user interface using icons, windows and graphical controls instead of text commands.

title: What is preemptive multitasking?
subject: OS
answer: OS forcibly interrupts running processes to give CPU to others based on scheduling policy.

title: What is a pipe?
subject: OS
answer: IPC mechanism allowing output of one process to be input of another. One-way communication.

title: Advantages of semaphores
subject: OS
answer: Simple, independent of hardware, avoid busy waiting, good for mutual exclusion and synchronization.

title: What is a bootstrap program?
subject: OS
answer: Initial program loaded at startup that initializes hardware and loads OS into memory.

title: What is IPC?
subject: OS
answer: Inter-process communication allows processes to share data and synchronize execution.

title: IPC mechanisms
subject: OS
answer: Pipes, Named Pipes, Message Queues, Semaphores, Shared Memory, Sockets.

title: Preemptive vs Non-preemptive scheduling
subject: OS
answer: Preemptive allows interruption of running process; non-preemptive runs until termination or blocking.

title: What is a zombie process?
subject: OS
answer: Finished execution but still has entry in process table waiting for parent to read exit status.

title: What is an orphan process?
subject: OS
answer: Child process whose parent terminated without waiting for it.

title: Starvation and aging
subject: OS
answer: Starvation occurs when process never gets CPU. Aging increases priority over time to avoid starvation.

title: Monolithic kernel
subject: OS
answer: Kernel where all services run in same address space, fast but large and harder to maintain.

title: What is context switching?
subject: OS
answer: Saving state of current process and loading state of next process so CPU can switch execution.

title: Difference between OS and Kernel
subject: OS
answer: OS is full system software including UI and tools. Kernel is core part managing resources and hardware interaction.

title: What is PCB?
subject: OS
answer: Process Control Block stores process state, registers, PC, memory info, scheduling info and resources.

title: When is a system in safe state?
subject: OS
answer: If there exists some order in which all processes can complete without deadlock.

title: What is cycle stealing?
subject: OS
answer: DMA temporarily borrows bus cycles from CPU to transfer data without CPU intervention.

title: What is a trap?
subject: OS
answer: Software-generated interrupt, often due to error or system call.

title: Program vs Process
subject: OS
answer: Program is passive stored code. Process is active execution with resources and state.

title: What is a dispatcher?
subject: OS
answer: Gives CPU control to process selected by scheduler and performs context switch.

title: Dispatch latency
subject: OS
answer: Time taken to stop one process and start another.

title: Goals of CPU scheduling
subject: OS
answer: Max CPU utilization, throughput and fairness; minimize waiting, turnaround and response time.

title: What is critical section?
subject: OS
answer: Part of program accessing shared resources that must not be executed by more than one process simultaneously.

title: Synchronization techniques
subject: OS
answer: Mutexes, Semaphores, Condition variables, File locks.

title: User vs Kernel threads
subject: OS
answer: User threads managed by user libraries; kernel threads managed by OS. Kernel threads can be scheduled individually.

title: Advantages of multithreading
subject: OS
answer: Better responsiveness, throughput, resource utilization and parallelism.

title: Multithreading vs Multitasking
subject: OS
answer: Multithreading: multiple threads inside one process. Multitasking: multiple processes share CPU.

title: Drawbacks of semaphores
subject: OS
answer: Priority inversion, risk of deadlocks, difficult debugging, programmer responsibility.

title: What is Peterson’s solution?
subject: OS
answer: Software algorithm ensuring mutual exclusion between two processes using flags and turn variable.

title: What is bounded waiting?
subject: OS
answer: There is a limit on number of times other processes can enter critical section before requesting process is granted access.

title: Solutions to critical section problem
subject: OS
answer: Software algorithms, hardware instructions, semaphores and monitors.

title: What is concurrency?
subject: OS
answer: Multiple processes exist and progress simultaneously, overlapping in time.

title: Drawbacks of concurrency
subject: OS
answer: Race conditions, starvation, deadlocks, overhead of synchronization and context switching.

title: Deadlock necessary conditions
subject: OS
answer: Mutual exclusion, hold-and-wait, no preemption and circular wait.

title: What is precedence graph?
subject: OS
answer: Directed acyclic graph showing execution ordering constraints between statements or processes.

title: Resource allocation graph
subject: OS
answer: Graph showing resource ownership and requests. Helps detect possible deadlock.

title: What is deadlock?
subject: OS
answer: Set of processes waiting indefinitely for resources held by each other.

title: Goals of memory management
subject: OS
answer: Relocation, protection, sharing, logical organization and physical organization.

title: Address binding
subject: OS
answer: Mapping logical addresses to physical addresses during compile, load or execution time.

title: Types of address binding
subject: OS
answer: Compile-time, Load-time and Execution-time binding.

title: Advantages of dynamic allocation
subject: OS
answer: Better memory utilization, flexible structures, easier insertion/deletion, supports unknown sizes at runtime.

title: Internal vs External fragmentation
subject: OS
answer: Internal: unused space inside allocated block. External: small free blocks scattered making allocation difficult.

title: What is compaction?
subject: OS
answer: Combining scattered free memory spaces into one contiguous block by relocating processes.

title: Paging vs Segmentation
subject: OS
answer: Paging uses fixed size blocks. Segmentation uses variable logical units like functions or arrays.

title: Associative vs Cache memory
subject: OS
answer: Associative is content-addressable memory. Cache is fast memory storing frequently used data.

title: Locality of reference
subject: OS
answer: Programs tend to access same or nearby memory locations repeatedly.

title: Advantages of virtual memory
subject: OS
answer: Supports large programs, allows multiprogramming, less fragmentation, more efficient memory use.

title: Effective access time formula
subject: OS
answer: EAT = (1 − p) × Memory access time + p × Page fault time

title: What is a file?
subject: OS
answer: Logical collection of related information stored on secondary storage.

title: File operations
subject: OS
answer: Create, Open, Read, Write, Append, Rename, Delete, Truncate, Close.

title: What is bit-vector?
subject: OS
answer: Array of bits indicating free and allocated disk blocks.

title: File Allocation Table (FAT)
subject: OS
answer: Table that maps each file to its disk blocks. Used for indexing and locating clusters.

title: Rotational latency
subject: OS
answer: Time for desired disk sector to rotate under read/write head.

title: Seek time
subject: OS
answer: Time taken for disk arm to move to correct track.

title: Belady’s anomaly
subject: OS
answer: In FIFO page replacement, increasing number of frames may increase page faults.

title: Recursive mutex re-lock behavior
subject: OS
answer: Locking non-recursive mutex twice may cause deadlock since same thread blocks on its own lock.

title: Advantages of multiprocessor systems
subject: OS
answer: Improved performance, parallel execution, reliability, higher throughput, resource sharing.

title: What are real-time systems?
subject: OS
answer: Systems where correctness depends on both logical results and timing deadlines.

title: Recovering from deadlock
subject: OS
answer: Abort processes, preempt resources, select victim, rollback to safe states.

title: Deadlock detection usage factors
subject: OS
answer: Based on likelihood of deadlock and number of processes affected when it occurs.

title: What is topological sorting used for?
subject: OS
answer: Orders tasks with dependencies such that each prerequisite appears before dependent task.

title: Resource Allocation Graph role
subject: OS
answer: Shows relationships between processes and resources, helps visualize and detect possible deadlocks.

title: What is paging replacement?
subject: OS
answer: Selecting which page to remove when memory is full using FIFO, LRU, Optimal etc.

title: Explain DMA
subject: OS
answer: Direct Memory Access allows devices to transfer data directly to memory without CPU involvement.

title: What is scheduler?
subject: OS
answer: Component deciding which process gets CPU next, using scheduling algorithms.

title: Difference between long, short and medium term scheduler
subject: OS
answer: Long term admits jobs, short term selects among ready processes, medium term swaps processes in/out of memory.

title: What is starvation?
subject: OS
answer: Process waits indefinitely because resources are continuously allocated to others.

title: Final: Resource Allocation Graph explanation
subject: OS
answer: RAG models processes and resources as nodes and edges showing assignment and request. Helps detect and reason about deadlocks.
